This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-11-27 22:32:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/30344). This forecasting question is associated with the Verity controversy: [Will Elon Musk's Million-Dollar Giveaway to Registered Voters Be Ruled Illegal?](https://www.verity.news/controversy/Will-Elon-Musks-milliondollar-giveaway-to-register-voters-be-ruled-illegal)

On 19 October 2024, Elon Musk, the tech multi-billionaire and the world’s richest man, announced [he was planning to give away $1 million daily to a swing state voter in the run-up to the United States presidential election on 5 November.](https://www.forbes.com/sites/mollybohannon/2024/10/20/elon-musk-giving-1-million-daily-to-swing-state-voters-who-sign-his-petition-in-latest-controversial-giveaway/) To be eligible for the gift, [voters had to sign a petition created by Musk’s political action committee America PAC and be registered in a swing state.](https://www.vox.com/politics/378912/musk-trump-voting-contest-million-dollars-swing-state-lottery-pennsylvania) According to Musk, the winners were not chosen randomly by a lottery draw but rather [“selected to earn $1m as a spokesperson for America PAC.](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/crlnjzzk919o)" [As GOP lawyer Chris Gober argued](https://www.pbs.org/newshour/politics/musks-pac-claims-1-million-winners-not-chosen-by-chance), “[t]he $1 million recipients are not chosen by chance. We know exactly who will be announced as the $1 million recipient today and tomorrow.” This is a departure from what Musk originally claimed, stating the giveaway was [“going to be award[ed] … randomly to people who have signed the petition”](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/crlnjzzk919o) at a campaign event. 
The giveaway, however, has not been without controversy. After its announcement, Elon Musk and America PAC’s actions came under significant scrutiny. Notably, Josh Shapiro, the Democratic governor of Pennsylvania, described the strategy as [“deeply concerning” and “something that law enforcement could take a look at.”](https://www.politico.com/live-updates/2024/10/20/2024-elections-live-coverage-updates-analysis/elon-musk-money-giveaway-josh-shapiro-00184523) Legal experts have also offered differing opinions on the giveaway’s legality. Richard Hasen, a legal scholar teaching at the University of California, Los Angeles, claimed that the giveaway was [“clearly illegal”](https://x.com/rickhasen/status/1847815868924715295). On the other hand, Bradley Smith, a Professor at Capital University Law School and former Professor at Capital University Law School, argued that whilst he could understand why it could be argued Musk’s tactic has broken the law, ultimately [“the better catch is that it does not."](https://youtu.be/I2eZhYqmP4U?si=XND0WFQdpabyFEjP&t=190) Others still, like Dave Aronberg and Kim Wyman, have stressed that any judgements would be premature, stating that Musk is operating in a [“gray zone”](https://www.newsweek.com/legal-analysts-react-dojs-election-warning-elon-musk-1974003) where [“the answer is not clear”](https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2024/10/24/elon-musk-pay-1-million-daily-voters-trump/75822067007/). 
So far, the giveaway has only resulted in [one lawsuit](https://www.forbes.com/sites/alisondurkee/2024/10/28/philadelphia-da-sues-elon-musks-pro-trump-pac-over-1-million-giveaway/). At the end of October, Philadelphia District Attorney Larry Krasner (a self-described "progressive prosecutor") took Musk and America PAC to court, accusing them of hatching an [“illegal lottery scheme to influence voters in that election.”](https://drive.google.com/file/d/13X8d5QADhuuPghc01ousqJeIzxtLO1kc/view?pli=1) However, after lawyers on behalf of Musk and America PAC revealed the giveaway was not a lottery, [Philadelphia Judge Angelo Foglietta refused to impose an injunction and ruled that the giveaway could continue.](https://www.forbes.com/sites/alisondurkee/2024/11/04/elon-musk-pacs-1-million-giveaways-upheld-in-court/)
Despite this, the opposition to Musk’s actions, and the open debate amongst legal experts about the giveaway’s legality, means that the possibility Musk and America PAC may be brought into court in the future cannot be ruled out, leaving the possibility open as to whether it will be ruled illegal.

The voters filed a lawsuit on November 5, 2024, alleging that Musk used a petition to sign in support of the US Constitution as a way to lure them into participating in the daily $1 million giveaway, which involved fraudulent behavior. Musk requested a judge to dismiss the lawsuit in January, stating that he had not organized an 'illegal' giveaway. However, a US federal judge ruled on August 20 that Musk must face the voters' legal challenge. US District Judge Robert Pitman stated in the ruling that Arizona voter Jacqueline McAferty had reasonably alleged that Musk and 'America PAC' misled her into providing personal information to participate in the giveaway by signing a petition in support of the US Constitution. McAferty alleged that Musk and America PAC lured seven swing state voters into signing the petition, promising to randomly select a daily $1 million winner, but the voters had no real chance of winning. She stated that the voters who signed the petition were asked to provide their name, address, email address, and phone number. Musk stated in January that the daily $1 million winner was 'selected to earn' the money, and the organizers of the activity had informed the voters that they would be reviewed to see if they could become a spokesperson for America PAC and earn $1 million. Therefore, he did not believe that the money was a prize. However, the judge pointed out that the plaintiff's statements showed that the defendants had 'awarded' $1 million, and that the money could be 'won.' The ruling stated: 'The plaintiff has a reasonable basis to rely on these statements, believing that the defendant objectively provided her with the opportunity to participate in a random draw -- even if the defendant subjectively did not intend to do so.' Regarding Musk's denial of the voters' claim that they were harmed by providing contact information. Judge Pitman stated that a political data intermediary expert could testify that the information was valuable to swing state voters. Musk and America PAC's lawyers have not commented on the latest ruling. This case is 'McAferty v. Musk,' US District Court for the Western District of Texas, Case No. 24-01346. In the day before the election, a Philadelphia judge refused to stop Musk's giveaway, citing that the city's district attorney had failed to prove that it was an illegal lottery.

Billionaire Elon Musk must face a lawsuit filed by voters who claim they were misled by him. According to the judge, this could have given voters the impression that it was a real lottery. The action targeted voters in seven swing states crucial for Trump's re-election. Signers were required to provide their name, address, email address, and phone number. Through a collective claim, the voters are seeking at least $5 million in damages.

**Elon Musk Faces Lawsuit Over Sweepstakes-Style Giveaway During 2024 US Presidential Election**
Elon Musk, the CEO of Tesla and the world's richest man, has been sued over a sweepstakes-style giveaway that he ran during the 2024 US presidential election. US District Judge Robert Pitman has ruled that Musk must face the lawsuit. According to Reuters, the lawsuit alleges that Musk and his political action committee, America PAC, used the giveaway to encourage voters to sign a petition in support of the US Constitution and collect their personal information. The lawsuit claims that Musk and America PAC ran the giveaway in seven key swing states, promising to randomly select a winner each day who would receive a $1 million prize, 'like a lottery', but in reality, participants had 'almost no chance of actually winning'. The lawsuit also alleges that signers of the petition were required to provide their name, address, email address, and phone number. Musk had previously established America PAC to support Republican candidate Donald Trump in the 2024 presidential election. The organization was accused of using the prize promise to boost the number of petition signatures. Musk's lawyers had previously asked the court to dismiss the lawsuit, citing 'obvious flaws' in the allegations, but Judge Pitman did not accept the motion and ruled that the lawsuit would continue. As of now, Musk's lawyers have not responded to media requests for comment. As the actual controller of Tesla, SpaceX, xAI, and social media platform X (formerly Twitter), Musk's public image is closely tied to his companies. This negative political news, which involves allegations of election fraud, may damage consumer trust in his brands and raise concerns among some investors and business partners. The case is ongoing.

**Elon Musk Must Face Lawsuit Over Alleged Fraud in Giveaway**
A US federal court has ruled that Elon Musk must face a lawsuit alleging fraud related to a giveaway. Judge Robert Pitman in Austin, Texas, sided with plaintiff Jacqueline McAferty, who claims Musk and his political action committee America PAC misled voters into providing personal data. Musk had founded America PAC to support Donald Trump's 2024 presidential campaign. He announced in October that he would give away $1 million daily to those who signed a petition and were registered voters in one of seven key swing states. McAferty said Musk and America PAC lured voters into signing the petition by promising they could win $1 million, but the signers had no real chance of receiving the money. They were also required to provide names, addresses, email addresses, and phone numbers. Musk had argued that the giveaway was not an illegal lottery, as the winners were chosen to 'earn' the money and were expected to serve as spokespeople for the committee. However, the judge rejected this argument, citing other statements from Musk that suggested the money was 'given' and 'won.' McAferty's lawyer said, 'It is plausible that the plaintiff relied on these statements.' Musk had also denied that the signers of the petition suffered any harm from providing their contact information. Pitman said an expert on political data brokerage could testify about the value of this information for voters in the contested states. The lawsuit was filed on election day, November 5, 2024.
